Gold poised for seventh monthly gain on geopolitical worries, softer US yields
data.description:
Feb 27 (Reuters) - Gold rose on Friday and was headed for a seventh straight month of gains, supported by geopolitical tensions after the United States and Iran extended nuclear talks, while softer U.S. Treasury yields further boosted bullion.

Spot gold was up 0.8% at $5,227.62 an ounce by 09:35 a.m. ET (1435 GMT). Prices climbed 7.4% so far in February.

U.S. gold futures for April delivery rose 0.9% to $5,242.10.

"There's a lot of nervousness surrounding geopolitics, you have all the set-up for a high probability of a military operation over the weekend so it's a risk-off in a flight to safety," said Phillip Streible, chief market strategist at Blue Line Futures.

The United States and Iran made progress in Thursday's nuclear talks, mediator Oman said, but hours of negotiations ended without a breakthrough that could avert possible U.S. strikes amid a major military buildup.

Meanwhile, the U.S. Embassy in Jerusalem also permitted non-emergency staff and families may leave Israel citing safety risks.

U.S. 10-year Treasury yields slipped to a three-month low, making non-yielding gold more attractive by lowering its opportunity cost.

Gold's next likely upside target is $5,450, with key support near $5,120, Streible said.

Data showed that U.S. producer prices increased more than expected in January, suggesting inflation could pick up in the months ahead.

Markets are pricing in about a 43.6% chance of a 25-basis-point U.S. Federal Reserve rate cut in June, as per the CME FedWatch tool.

Elsewhere, top consumer China's net gold imports via Hong Kong in January rose by 68.7% from December, Hong Kong Census and Statistics Department data showed.

China's central bank moved to curb the yuan's rise by removing risk-reserve rules for forex forwards, encouraging more dollar buying.

Spot silver rose 3.4% to $91.31 an ounce, on course for a 7.8% monthly gain.

Spot platinum climbed 3.5% to $2,352.25 an ounce while palladium was up 0.1% at $1,785.25. Both the metals were headed for monthly gains.

(Reporting by Anmol Choubey in Bengaluru; Editing by Diti Pujara)

By Anmol Choubey

Japan Faces Balancing Act to Stabilize Yen, Keep Debt Servicing Costs Sustainable -- Interview
data.description:
By Emese Bartha


Japanese policymakers will need to strike a delicate balance as they seek to stabilize the yen and keep debt services costs on Japan's significant debt manageable, Eva Sun-Wai, fund manager at M&G Investments said.

Japan's government plans aggressive fiscal stimulus to protect the country's fragile domestic growth. At the same time, the central bank will likely need to raise interest rates to fight persistent inflation.

They will need to do this without increasing the national debt, which is estimated between 235% and 250% of GDP.

"Japan has always had quite a difficult combination of needing to keep interest rates low so that they don't massively increase their debt servicing costs but not keeping rates so low that the currency deteriorates meaningfully," she said.

This balancing act was recently tested when long-dated Japanese government bond yields surged to record highs ahead of the Lower House election on Feb. 8 due to investor concerns over potentially unsustainable fiscal stimulus.

Yields have since retreated. Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi's landslide victory ensured political stability. It reinforced her mandate to pursue expansive fiscal policies, but Takaichi has repeatedly stressed that her government will act fiscally responsibly.

The Japanese yen has also recovered after falling to an 18-month low of 159.45 yen per U.S. dollar in mid-January, LSEG data show. The dollar last traded at 155.96 yen.

One of the main risks Sun-Wai sees is of potential for large-scale repatriation of offshore assets--including U.S. Treasurys--back into Japanese government bonds as the Bank of Japan increases interest rates from their current low level of 0.75% and yields rise.

Such a move could be disruptive, potentially causing big selling in U.S. Treasurys, especially as the U.S. Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates further, she says. However, she considers this a low risk.

"I don't see the repatriation flow argument as rapid a risk as people say," she said. "I still see it a risk, but I don't think it would happen quickly."

A weak yen and negative real yields are among the factors that would discourage rapid asset repatriation, she said.

Most Japanese investors are structural, long?term holders of offshore government bonds for liability-management reasons. These positions aren't leveraged, so there is no risk of rapid margin-call dynamics, she said.

External factors which could prompt big selling in U.S. Treasurys and the dollar do pose a risk, however.

These could include the Fed cutting rates more aggressively than expected by markets, U.S. policy uncertainty and Fed independence risks. Still, Fed independence concerns have receded with former Fed governor Kevin Warsh's nomination to Fed Chair, she said.

Given entrenched inflation in Japan, the BOJ "will likely need to embark on some sort of rate hike cycle, even if it's very slow and steady," she said.

"Even if it means that it's just to give them room in the next downturn so that they can cut [rates] and stimulate the economy."

BOJ rate hikes will likely result in a 'bear flattening' of the Japanese bond yield curve, Sun-Wai said. This is where short-term rates rise faster than long-term rates, usually due to expectations of central bank interest-rate hikes. U.S. Treasurys show the opposite trend, with the yield curve steepening.

Japan is now shifting from a trend over the last few decades, when it favoured bolster economic growth via a weaker yen which in turn bolstered exports, Sun-Wai said.

M&G Investments had 365 billion pounds ($491.63 billion) in assets under management as at Sept. 30, 2025.


Write to Emese Bartha at emese.bartha@wsj.com


(END) Dow Jones Newswires

02-27-26 1009ET

Amazon and OpenAI strengthen their strategic alliance in AI
data.description:
Amazon and OpenAI are continuing to unite in the artificial intelligence ecosystem through a new strategic partnership. Both groups have announced the creation of a runtime environment based on OpenAI's models, which will be available via Amazon Bedrock. This infrastructure is intended to enable AWS customers to design, deploy and manage applications as well as generative AI agents.

As part of the deal, AWS will become the exclusive third-party cloud distribution provider for OpenAI Frontier. Companies will be able to rely on Amazon's infrastructure to build and orchestrate teams of artificial intelligence agents. OpenAI and AWS are also expanding their existing multi-year agreement, increasing it from $38bn to $100bn over eight years. The extension notably aims for OpenAI to use about 2 gigawatts of Trainium capacity via AWS infrastructure, further strengthening technological integration between both partners.

The new agreement comes after a major Amazon investment in OpenAI during the start-up's latest fundraising round. The companies said Amazon's total $50bn commitment would first take the form of an initial $15bn investment, followed by another $35bn "in the coming months, once certain conditions are met."

ICE Canola : China Announces Expected Tariff Move
data.description:
WINNIPEG, Manitoba--Canola futures on the Intercontinental Exchange turned around to pull back on Friday morning, after posting gains in the overnight session.

China announced that it is suspending its 100% tariff on imports of Canadian agricultural products, effective March 1.

This is part of a trade deal Canada struck with China in January. The move includes China's levy on canola meal, while its surcharge on canola seed drops to 15%.

Crude oil was sharply higher, with the spillover underpinning the Chicago soy complex, MATIF rapeseed and Malaysian palm oil.

Ample canola supplies from Canada's record harvest and the strong likelihood of large ending stocks continued to hover on the market.

Statistics Canada is set to release its planted acre projections on Thursday. With the farmer surveys completed before the Canada-China trade deal, there may be more canola seeded for 2026/27 than anticipated.

The March canola contract was quickly becoming less relevant as Friday marked first notice day for March futures.

The Canadian dollar was higher on Friday morning, with the loonie at 73.20 U.S. cents compared with Thursday's close of 73.06.

Approximately 20,550 contracts had been traded by 9:38 a.m. EST and prices in Canadian dollars per metric ton were: 


 
           Price      Change 
Mar       677.70     dn 2.90 
May       690.60     dn 2.40 
Jul       701.40     dn 2.20 
Nov       695.90     dn 2.00

Source: Commodity News Service Canada, news@marketsfarm.com


(END) Dow Jones Newswires

02-27-26 1001ET

Dell shares at three-month highs on forecast it will double AI server revenue
data.description:
Feb 27 (Reuters) - Shares of Dell Technologies jumped 17.5% on Friday after the company forecast revenue from its AI server business will double in fiscal 2027, underscoring surging demand for infrastructure catering to artificial intelligence.

Investors also cheered the PC maker's plans for a 20% hike to cash dividends and an additional $10 billion share repurchase program.

Dell's shares surged to a three-month high. Trading at $142.31, it was on track to mark its biggest one-day jump in nearly two years.

Data center equipment makers such as Dell have benefited from the rapid expansion in AI investors, with sector leaders expected to spend at least $630 billion this year.

Dell said it expects AI server revenue to grow 103% to about $50 billion in fiscal 2027.

At least seven Wall Street brokerages raised price targets on the stock, with J.P.Morgan expecting it to rally at least 36%, from Thursday's close, in the next one year to $165.

Dell's ability to navigate cyclical challenges stems from its leadership position in AI compute for Tier 2 Cloud and Enterprises, where the significant revenue inflection is able to provide the company a lot more flexibility in managing operating margin and earnings outcomes, analysts led by Samik Chatterjee at J.P.Morgan wrote in a note.

Dell's other big business, PC manufacturing, is navigating higher memory chip costs, as companies shift resources to building AI data centers.

However, the company has been able to deal with rising prices better than rivals such as HP Inc and China's Lenovo Group.

The surging costs could hit Dell's gaming PC business as memory processors are essential to videogame systems, enabling quick load times, smooth frame rates and overall performance.

Market researcher TrendForce upwardly revised its first-quarter 2026 Dynamic Random Access Memory price growth rate to 90% to 95% from the previous quarter.

Dell's shares have starkly outperformed those of HP and Lenovo over the past one year.

(Reporting by Johann M Cherian and Zaheer Kachwala in Bengaluru; Editing by Krishna Chandra Eluri)

Liquidation order for MBaer Merchant Bank is effective, watchdog says
data.description:
Feb 27 (Reuters) - Swiss financial regulator FINMA said on Friday that a liquidation order for MBaer Merchant Bank AG was now effective after Washington threatened to cut the Swiss private bank's access to the U.S. financial system for breaching sanctions against Iran, Russia and Venezuela.

FINMA concluded enforcement proceedings against MBaer three weeks ago, but due to an MBaer appeal, which the bank withdrew on Friday, FINMA was previously unable to implement its own measures, it said.

In the course of its proceedings, FINMA found that the bank did not have adequate measures in place to combat money laundering and enabled clients to circumvent official asset freezes, it added.

"The case is extremely serious," the regulator said.

"Through its conduct and inadequate organisation, (the bank)exposed itself and the Swiss financial centre to disproportionately high risks," FINMA added.

(Reporting by Linda Pasquini, editing by Thomas Seythal)
